Reviews: This review comes perhaps after 19 years, as at the time there was no internet Today, I am grateful I ended up at NYU Fertility Center in the year 2000 with the best Doctor ever: Dr Licciardi (I just saw on their website he is still there and I know he is a great asset to NYU Fertility Center) Dr Licciardi was my doctor but I saw him only twice during the process We met at the consult and then he preformed one ultrasound I really thought Dr Licciardi's care was excellent during the process I definitely felt that he cared and I wasn't just another number in the factory I think Dr Licciardi wanted to manage my expectations because he told me to expect 10-14 eggs, but 22 were retrieved and 20 mature eggs were frozen (age 36)Dr Licciardi is an angel He changed my life! I emphatically recommend him!! Based on my extensive research, I learned that Dr Grifo is one of the most prominent IVF experts in the country and that he has had personal experience with IVF in his own family One of the most important things to look for is that the doctor studies your charts after each test and adjusts the medication and protocol accordingly to maximize your chances for a positive outcome Dr Grifo does exactly that He seems to know exactly what to do in more difficult situations like mine where the body doesn't react to the medicine quickly In the end, I had much better results than the first time at another clinic due to the above attention to detail and correct adjustments to the meds made along the wayI (40 year old) am holding my miracle child after 10 years of infertility and IF treatments (previous patient at Cornell and Columbia (stay far away from here!!!)Dr Berkeley took my rare case (less than 1% of his patients) and believed they could help meI've sent several friends to Dr Berkely with confidence and would send my sister (if I had one! ) to him She was prepared for our session, explained our options clearly, and was able to order the necessary tests to help us build our probe (that we eventually used for a successful pregnancy via IVF)Medical care was not satisfactory5, then went to 5, and then 7 Also did a saline sonogram here, and there were literally chunks of my cervix on the floor after because it took the Doc FOUR tries to get the speculum and catheter in properly Every phone/email interaction took no less than THREE tries  I was NOT disappointed!  In every step of the process, I was greeted with warm, friendly, attentive nurses and methodical doctorsWould recommend, would do again, and will definitely go to NYU for any future fertility care I may need in the future Initial consult w/ Dr Noyes  She was good at making me feel comfortable with the process She also smartly rejected my initial low AMH results (  Personally I didn't feel much the first 5 days of stims By the time they had me on ganirelix I did feel twinges in my abdomen and felt bloated  I also think a call at least once during the cycle from the doctor of your initial consult would help immensely to improve 'feel' However - my main goal was to go through this process in safe hands and I felt that was the case with NYU No effort to try anything They don't really care about your financial and don't listen when you point out their mistakesI really can't say anything positive  It's a factory  They "explain" things to you as if you work there and do all these things every day, but most of us do each of the things we need to do in this process one time and have no idea what NYU is talking about  But with very few (like one person) exceptions, they don't care about you at all  People who are "coordinating" things say things like, "Did you tell so and so?" And you're thinking "I emailed every person with an email address, am I supposed to personally call every person whose name I've ever heard at NYU until I reach them after going through the switchboard? Isn't that, perhaps, your job? They are, of course, totally on top of billing - that part is always very clear and taken care of first and foremostI've heard bad things about Cornell (and nothing positive), so I wouldn't recommend them eitherDr Grifo is my phenomenal doctor who came highly recommended and has lived up to his word-of-mouthDr Noyes is also freaking amazing Number two: she has had a great sense of humor, a jovial, approachable manner, and a clear underlying focus on results whenever I've interacted with her Dr Noyes will cut through that insidious optimism and help you make statistically informed decisions I also highly recommend Dr Fino - another experienced straight shooter who will not BS you about what to expectAs for having a whole team of doctors available:  this is so much better than going back to the same person over and over again Although this procedure is elective, donors should be entitled to understand potential medical complications I do not feel confident that the health of donors is given enough consideration at NYU - there are other options in the city)I contacted our health plan's fertility nurse when my husband & I decided to conceive They care for pregnancies up to 10 weeks, so I figured I'd stick with them in case of miscarriage1/3 - First appointment, chatted with Dr Noyes, had a blood draw to confirm pregnancy (There are studies about behavioral problems in chicks and rats exposed to ultrasound in utero, so I'm trying to limit ultrasounds She said they didn't check because Dr Noyes "doesn't believe in supplementing with progesterone" to prevent miscarriage The doctor who performed the ultrasound was kind, said everything was normal, and we got to take pictures and a video of our baby's heartbeat"I later emailed Dr Noyes (she didn't respond) and called the office to clarifyWe went through several painful failed IVF rounds here And when we contact the billing center to discuss (more than 10 times at this point), they claim there is some secret "Accounts Receivable" person who makes all the decisions who we are not allowed to talk to directlyDr Licciardi is absolutely amazing Dr Licciardi listened to us carefully, provided his recommendations clearly and confidently, and ultimately helped us conceive our first baby in three months of treatment! I would recommend Dr Licciardi to anyone looking for a warm, knowledgable, caring support on the journey to conception I only met with Dr Noyes once during the process I had a friend help me with this process, but the Center should be able to provide more training and support at this point I recommended a friend to the Center who had a similar experience  When I spoke to others at the office, they kept telling me to call her  She finally called me back over a week later and told me she had been on vacation - apparently no one was covering for her and no one knew she was on vacation  As a patient, I've continued to experience this type of disorganization with each cycle  I felt like i was being jerked around  Just wish the rest of the experience was more pleasant and straight forward 1) You feel like you are in a vacuum But since they don't talk to each other, you are always told different story 2) My husband called 2 weeks prior (and I also wrote them an email) to confirm his appointment for providing his semen, and sure enough, they didn't have his name for that day All of that, it took them 45 minutes to figure out, and after he was told numerous times that he did not have an appointment  * I only spoke with Dr Berkley once on the initial visit  I felt that Dr Berkley was not involved in the decision making/ guidance after the initial visit  * I and the NYU staff was not able to communicate with Dr Berkley in regards to issue that were time sensitive* Overall while I am sure that Dr Berkley is an expert in the infertility treatment, I personally did not feel that his care was different/exceptional from other physicians and that NYU internal workflow/communication was the worst I have ever seen  This place is just EXTREMELY difficult to deal withNYU Fertility Center changed my life IVF is a very difficult process physically and emotionally, but the team at NYU is caring, knowledgeable and very well coordinated Dr Grifo was my doctor, and yes, while I didn't see him every cycle, he was always available by phone and my husband and I often set up calls with him to check in and he did design and adjust my meds with each cycle and day-to-day, especially towards the time of retrieval They are clear in their results and straightforward On my last day there I receive a warm goodbye and I felt cared for And pregnant, which I am deeply grateful to the team there for Twelve thumbs up for Dr Licciardi and his staff We couldn't be happier with the care we received there  In this consultation, he/she first reviews your medical history and talks you through it, and also provides a detailed overview of the process, and statistical chances of success  Before you leave, you get your egg count  My doctor was Dr Liccardi, who was very nice and knowledgable, and called me the day I started stims to make sure I was ok  I did at times wish I had a direct line to someone, but I realize they are busy treating patients and not sitting by the phone)  But overall, I'm extremely pleased with my experience and highly recommend NYU to anyone considering an egg freeze cycleI had a nightmarish experience at this center, and with Dr Grifo  I will add my two cents and will try to be as fair and intelligent as possible in my thoughts, because, if you are reading this, you are contemplating some big stuff in your life!Disclaimer: my partner and I did this electively - we froze our embryos - and we are not trying to conceive at this time   So I might have had higher expectations for this place, having not been in a situation where I felt that I had no other options) in her two main points: 1)  If you want results, you are as likely to get them here as anywhere else2)  They are NOT into giving "more emotional type support to their clients"  I can say that Dr Grifo is awesome, too, because I had some contact with him also  Sometimes it felt like they were taking the "care" out of medical care  They really don't provide the support for the emotions that you will experience, or even the physical pain, so you have to find this support elsewhere   When I think about it, this is crazy to me, because, by all accounts, stress and anxiety are really bad for fertility, but they don't seem to give a crap about any stress or anxiety you are feeling  I think it will make you crazy to second-guess the doctors here, but hey, hormones make you do crazy things!  Anything having to do with making babies is an inexact science, that's just the way it is  It is also an emerging and changing field  They are way more focused on the next generation than on this oneI'm not a big poster, but I feel compelled to do so here - especially given some of these bad reviews They often remember you (not sure how when they see hundreds of patients), and I've never felt unwelcome or rushed My doc followed up on every procedure, and I knew she was available if needed Highly recommend!We are patients of Dr Grifo and couldn't have had a better experience and are sooo thankful for his expertise  We had several failed attempts to have a child in the state we live in  We went in for our first visit with Dr Grifo and, even though I had an incredibly large history file for him to review, he knew exactly what to try from day 1  Dr Grifo  is unbelievably brilliant, he gave us great advice along the way, he addressed all our questions and concerns, and their clinic is state-of-the-art in technical advancements  We are now expecting our first baby soon and couldn't say enough positive things about NYU and specifically Dr Grifo  Our first clinic was definitely giving more emotional type support to their clients, but that got us no where in the end I called the number on the statement to inquire about the additional $950, she tells me that there's no record of the $6950 payment My dr was DR Keefe, who spend some time with us during initial consultation, however it was very difficult to get a hold of him directly for any questions after that The doctor who ended up giving the ultrasound asked why I came in so late  When I finally spoke to my doctor, I felt like she was talking down to me despite the fact that I am a healthcare professional and this isn't my first IVF  I felt like she couldn't even be bothered with explaining her decision to me  The MDs do not seem invested in patient care
summary: to him She was prepared for our session, explained our options clearly, and was able to order the necessary tests to help us build our probe (that we eventually used for a successful pregnancy via IVF)Medical care was not satisfactory5, then went to 5, and then 7 Also did a saline sonogram here, and there were literally chunks of my cervix on the floor after because it took the Doc FOUR tries to get the speculum and catheter in properly Every phone/email interaction took no less than THREE tries . They explain things to you as if you work there and do all these things every day, but most of us do each of the things we need to do in this process one time and have no idea what NYU is talking about . And you're thinking I emailed every person with an email address, am I supposed to personally call every person whose name I've ever heard at NYU until I reach them after going through the switchboard? She finally called me back over a week later and told me she had been on vacation - apparently no one was covering for her and no one knew she was on vacation . As a patient, I've continued to experience this type of disorganization with each cycle . I only spoke with Dr Berkley once on the initial visit . I and the NYU staff was not able to communicate with Dr Berkley in regards to issue that were time sensitive* Overall while I am sure that Dr Berkley is an expert in the infertility treatment, I personally did not feel that his care was different/exceptional from other physicians and that NYU internal workflow/communication was the worst I have ever seen . In this consultation, he/she first reviews your medical history and talks you through it, and also provides a detailed overview of the process, and statistical chances of success . Before you leave, you get your egg count . My doctor was Dr Liccardi, who was very nice and knowledgable, and called me the day I started stims to make sure I was ok . I did at times wish I had a direct line to someone, but I realize they are busy treating patients and not sitting by the phone) . They are NOT into giving more emotional type support to their clients . I can say that Dr Grifo is awesome, too, because I had some contact with him also . Sometimes it felt like they were taking the care out of medical care . When I think about it, this is crazy to me, because, by all accounts, stress and anxiety are really bad for fertility, but they don't seem to give a crap about any stress or anxiety you are feeling . Anything having to do with making babies is an inexact science, that's just the way it is . It is also an emerging and changing field . We went in for our first visit with Dr Grifo and, even though I had an incredibly large history file for him to review, he knew exactly what to try from day 1 . We are now expecting our first baby soon and couldn't say enough positive things about NYU and specifically Dr Grifo . I felt like she couldn't even be bothered with explaining her decision to me . The MDs do not seem invested in patient care

Reviews: Second, no one is going to hold your hand during the process I was cursing the center's name during my first injection as I felt that they could have done more to prepare me Third, your doctor may not do the actual retrieval All of the doctors are highly skilled with decades of experience so you will always be in great hands What this actually means I really don't know because Dr Licciardi made it clear that there are no guarantees You have to go into this knowing that you are going to drop thousands of dollars I initially was going to go to a less expensive center and then I thought is this really the time for me to be frugal??? These are your future children You owe it to your future self to go to the best provider Sixth, be realistic I'm doing this knowing that I have no control over the future outcome I have to be okay with the thought that nothing is guaranteed Do your research and be proactive, but love yourself no matter what happens He truly cares about his patients and wants the best for them Disappointed in those results, I researched other practices and doctors in NYC to try to have better results for my last cycle covered by insurance  I hope to go back for a sibling and hope that if you go here you walk away with your miracle Don't seem like a Doc even reviewed my cycle records until I asked Found out after the fact only a tiny 5 ft, 100 lb woman should be on a 2 Please note, it has never taken another Doc more than 1 try  I recommend bringing your SO (if you have one) so that you can do your paperwork together under supervision  The ultrasound was always done by a doctor (though not always *your* doctor) About the shots:  Mixing Menopur takes a lot more time than expected!  Prepare to spend ~20 min each night setting everything up and take extra precautions to ensure you are doing it right When you get there, it's a quick review of your medical history before setting you up on a surgical chair (w/ very high stirrups) Note - the retrieval doctor is unlikely to be *your* doctor (from the consult); fine by me, but some people may not realize this going in Recovery: Once you have demonstrated your vitals are ok and you can use the bathroom on your own they send you out with a few docs about what to do/not to do and look for over the next week You are also told your egg count (mine was 12) I suspect that this is the norm and so want to emphasize it since most boards are filled with negative experiences I would have been pleased with this, except that they needed to use ICSI for fertilization  Instead, we ended up spending a LOT of money on ICSI, and also being concerned /frustrated that we had to choose among a poor sperm sample  That was the most important part for me Just see that you are above 40 and tell you that your only hope is to use donor eggs I would advise anyone above 40 (women) NOT to pursue treatment here This was told to me by 2 separate providers in this same practice Or else never would I choose to work with these physicians Many of the rest don't even have direct phone numbers - so it is sort of a ridiculous joke trying to reach people at various critical stages  Maybe try CCRM?  Or get out of New York if you can  I was annoyed when I realized this, but I can't say I was surprised Dr Leeds was my doctor and was honest with me about the chances for success and limits to the procedure This demonstrates to me that they did their job well Still no certainties what will happen, but they skills gave me the best chance possibleAsk questions and do your research intelligently: The NY Department of Health guidebook for egg donors mentioned by another reviewer is already 20 years old (1998!) and hasn't been updated since Look instead at the most recent literature from the medical community and to sources you can trust for expert and accurate advice Research is ongoing, so they freeze the immature eggs in hopes that fertility science has had some breakthroughs by the time the eggs are thawed for use Still, it's important to keep in mind that this process is basically a scientific miracle Having a child genetically related to oneself following cancer or into one's 40s is a triumph of technology over the harsher side of nature I am impressed with his intellect and dedication to continuing research in fertility This guy does not quit He is exactly who you want on your make-a-baby team I read on here that maybe she isn't always warm and fuzzy Number 1: Who cares!? She is a scientist and surgeon, not a therapist I was laughing and talking about gelato as I waited for the anesthesia to kick in Then I had an effortless, painless recovery Dr Noyes is rigorous, meticulous, courageously honest about what patients can expect and should do, and dedicated to high performance standards Note:  Dr Noyes is the most statistically oriented of the doctors with whom I've interacted If you are a logical, statistical thinker, you will get sick of all the anecdotal and narrative evidence batted around in fertility forums and between moms The way this clinic is set this up, patients have access to second, third, and fourth opinions during their cycles Empower yourselves and use the team of doctors to your advantage Way better than reading fertility forums which tend to be overly optimistic This is when I myself started to get concerned Consider where you go carefully - your health matters, too This was the first I'd heard of this I asked her to re-do it in a sanitary way, as I've developed infections from ultrasounds previously1/22 - Called to get my test results from 1/20 (Idk how this is possible because I caught chickenpox and had two MMR vaccines"Me: "Ok, so I guess I should have this baby and get the vaccines right after and then I won't be getting pregnant within 30 days?"Nurse: "Well you need to get the vaccine before you get pregnant, so you don't want to wait I won't be going back, as the potential for great medical error with this system is alarming Why not?! So bizarre His warmth and understanding put us at ease right awayMy experience with Yelp reviews is that they are mostly either excellent or disastrous, and so I am writing to give a more nuanced picture There was a training session to explain the egg freezing process and ask questions, as all the language around different hormones and cycles can be overwhelmingI think the doctors are top-notch here and they are worth coming here for, but the support staff needs reorganization  Several months ago, I was told that I had to speak with a particular person at billing before I had a procedure Others I've spoken with have also experienced itDespite this, I think my doctor is great They in the end explained how the lab was not ready that day, and they didn't know till that morning 4) They told me that I need to book an appointment with Dr Berkley to complain about all of the above  You have to constantly follow-up  This was over six months ago and we are still trying to resolve it  Such a shame they can't treat their patients better  I'd look for other options Yes they don't hold your hand but they really deliver  (This is a long review, but I wanted to describe the whole experience  Then you do an initial consultation with the doctor you chose  Then, he/she does an examination to make sure everything looks in order down there)  After that, you're ready to start whenever you're ready  This is the amount extracted, diagram of the female reproductive system), with the most relevant info (dos and don'ts) kind of mixed in easy to forget I had repeated failed cycles here, and questioned their earlier representations to me I found Dr Grifo's behavior to be unprofessional and beneath the standards I would expect for a physician - despite the fact that he delayed my procedure due to their on-the-spot demands for money - he had the gall and distaste to say to me that he could have made $3,000 during the time he was speaking to me I found the experience traumatic and, as mentioned earlier, repeated cycles were entirely unsuccessfulWe had Dr Keefe, and he is awesome  One of the best doctors I've ever worked with  He made an immediate connection with us and I really value that  But unfortunately, you spend very little of your time here with your doc  If I had once piece of feedback for this place, it would be to please only hire people with a decent bedside manner, especially those who work directly with patients  I wanted to tattoo my name and date of birth on my forehead, from getting asked so many times  My other negative is that they really just don't prepare you for the enormity of what you are going through  (I suggest hooking up with someone who has been through it before and putting them on speed-dial on your phone)  Nobody will ever simply ask you how you are feeling  I overheard a couple other ladies questioning their medicine doses and the timing of their procedures, and I just would caution against going down that road  But I believe that this place has the most data, the most information, to base their decisions on  There may be students in some of your appointments  (I'm all for it because it will help future couples conceive, but if you don't want a student in there, just speak up and say so  They are tiny now  Try not to over-worry this partThe other "good" thing, if you can call it that, is that the procedure, which I spent a lot of time dreading, it no bigs either  They put you in what they call, and I am not kidding, "twilight sedation", which is great  The anesthesiologist stays with you the whole time  The sedation is awesomeSo, the bottom line for me is: this is a results-oriented medical clinic that will not hold your hand through any of this  Which is, after all, their joband I now know whythis is especially impressive since everyone else had no idea how to proceed  When you go to the best of the best, you DO get different results  Let them do what they do best  They work with Walgreens and Livestrong to get you all of your hormones free of charge Figure out a better system because this is unfair to your patients I don't remember what Doctor handled our implantation- but she was fantastic In the end the doctors and nurses all know what they are doing and you can trust them - but the communication is lacking and frustrating for a patient who has never gone through fertility treatment before Maybe a smaller facility will be more hands on but have less caregivers which may cause other issues In the end we are happy with our IVF baby girl and it was worth any aggravation we had at the time  The first problem occurred when the secretary gave me the wrong appointment time and date  It was in her handwriting, so she knew she wrote it wrong and all she could do was apologize profusely  Ultimately, I decided not to have my procedure done here, because I don't trust them at all The doctors are amazing, and very approachable Everything is digital, and everyone is on board at all times In particular, we loved Dr Keefe  They seem to be just coasting through the process The entire process was disappointing
summary: These are your future children You owe it to your future self to go to the best provider Sixth, be realistic I'm doing this knowing that I have no control over the future outcome I have to be okay with the thought that nothing is guaranteed Do your research and be proactive, but love yourself no matter what happens He truly cares about his patients and wants the best for them Disappointed in those results, I researched other practices and doctors in NYC to try to have better results for my last cycle covered by insurance . Mixing Menopur takes a lot more time than expected! . I was annoyed when I realized this, but I can't say I was surprised Dr Leeds was my doctor and was honest with me about the chances for success and limits to the procedure This demonstrates to me that they did their job well Still no certainties what will happen, but they skills gave me the best chance possibleAsk questions and do your research intelligently: The NY Department of Health guidebook for egg donors mentioned by another reviewer is already 20 years old (1998!) So bizarre His warmth and understanding put us at ease right awayMy experience with Yelp reviews is that they are mostly either excellent or disastrous, and so I am writing to give a more nuanced picture There was a training session to explain the egg freezing process and ask questions, as all the language around different hormones and cycles can be overwhelmingI think the doctors are top-notch here and they are worth coming here for, but the support staff needs reorganization . This was over six months ago and we are still trying to resolve it . Such a shame they can't treat their patients better . I'd look for other options Yes they don't hold your hand but they really deliver . ( Then you do an initial consultation with the doctor you chose . Then, he/she does an examination to make sure everything looks in order down there) . After that, you're ready to start whenever you're ready . He made an immediate connection with us and I really value that . If I had once piece of feedback for this place, it would be to please only hire people with a decent bedside manner, especially those who work directly with patients . My other negative is that they really just don't prepare you for the enormity of what you are going through . ( I overheard a couple other ladies questioning their medicine doses and the timing of their procedures, and I just would caution against going down that road . But I believe that this place has the most data, the most information, to base their decisions on . There may be students in some of your appointments . ( Try not to over-worry this partThe other good thing, if you can call it that, is that the procedure, which I spent a lot of time dreading, it no bigs either . The anesthesiologist stays with you the whole time . Which is, after all, their joband I now know whythis is especially impressive since everyone else had no idea how to proceed . The first problem occurred when the secretary gave me the wrong appointment time and date . They seem to be just coasting through the process The entire process was disappointing

Reviews: I also remember a very caring and nice nurse, I am not sure I am spelling her name properly: Nurse Oana (I think she was from Romania or an Eastern European country, not sure) anyway, all the nurses were very supportive during this emotional journey He was always accessible by phone and email, and he called me several times to keep me updated and to check on me He is compassionate, smart, caring, available, etc She was responsive, knowledgeable and easy to work with They kept saying they were sent via mail, but after me calling every week for over a month the admin realized the folder had been sitting on a desk but never picked up Meet patient coordinator:  She was supposed to be my main point of contact over the next few weeks, though after paperwork/insurance was handled, I never spoke with her again  Monitoring also makes you feel like you're in a spy movie; every day you are told to "await a phone call with further instructions Examples: Few of them have email address (at least that they will provide) The same nurse (I think) said that nurses don't look at patients' records when they call with test results Unfortunately, it seems that the staff does not communicate very well The give clear, individualized instructions and are available to answer questions The nurses are caring and compassionate and the embryology team is very good  The next day, a nurse calls you and tells you how many of those were able to be freezed, and of those, how many are mature They were beyond rude and horrendous to me If you have an emergency, leave a message via the call center and someone gets back you right away Phone calls post-testing or procedure have always been timely, and they make sure you understand all instructions He's truly sweet and honestly caring, on top of being an amazing expert He was open to trying new things, and answered every question I sent, at any time of dayThe nurses gossip about the MDs constantly

Reviews: They have a great team and I have to thank them for having given me the most precious gift I have: my daughter Life Is full of surprises as now 19 years after, my daughter is a freshman at NYU! I had an excellent experience, but I can see why some people may have complaints Here are a few points to consider:First, it is a factory but an organized one Actually, it gave me comfort to know that the center is a well oiled machine  You may see the same nurses during blood work, but often they are different They were all excellent Get there at 7 am to avoid the wait for blood work I felt completely unprepared when it was time to do my first injection I read the directions and then watched the videos It probably took me an hour to do my first two injections Fast forward to Day 4, I was a pro at administering the injections (less than 10 minutes)Fourth, you will get excellent results My insurer was giving me the runaround and I couldn't wait any longer What is meant to be will beI am happy to say that I had a good experience with Dr Grifo at NYU and much better results than at another clinic (which I also reviewed) Be aware!I also encountered issues with NYU's and specifically the anesthesiology department's billing practices  I loved the whole clinic - minus a nurse or two- but on the whole- have loved my experience with them- ans again- this wasn't my first time aroundlike any Infertility clinic- it gets busy- but never felt like the cattle call at CornellGenetic counselor, Andria was the only bright spot at this clinic (have been to 3 clinics at this point)Administrative support here was probably the worst part of this clinic Was frustrating to schedule appointments and get questions answered by the nurses When it got sent to me, more than half of the records were missing, but luckily the few items I needed where there   You will feel like a product on an assembly line, but that's a good thing; you'll get the impression that NYU has done this many, many times before The morning visits were smooth and calm It was my first time going under anesthesia, and I was terrified--but the whole thing ended up being just as efficient as the rest of my care at NYU  I am now one day post-op and have no pain at allExperience at NYU Fertility Center in May 2018; I was 353 Orientation:  This provided useful information on how everything would proceed Process begins!  You show up for monitoring (blood draw + ultrasound) on day 2 of your period  Monitoring is something you'll be doing a lot of; it's quick (~20 min), and then you are on your way (maybe leading to the factory feel that some have reported, but I liked the expediency)About monitoring:  I felt like the nurses were great, caring and competent"  Later, the call comes with info about how much medication to take  For me, recovery wasn't bad I did not accept Tylenol and felt like I had very bad cramps for the rest of the day but they improved by day 2  Apparently, my husband's sperm (which he provided a few weeks earlier and looked 'great' at the time) - did not come out of frozen in a good state  I was *extremely* frustrated by this and consider it a huge fault of NYU that they did not inform us of this possibility (there was ample time for my husband to come back to provide more specimens) Overall I would consider the experience generally positive due to the quality of people at NYU and feeling in safe hands  On the negative side: the front office is extremely disorganized (don't discount other reviews about this; be vigilant about your paperwork and double check everything!) Recommendations for NYU:  I think the biggest issue for NYU in terms of 'feel' is the lack of a single point of contact for your cycle  I assumed the patient coordinator would be that, but I didn't interact with her again once I started my cycle  If they could somehow ensure a single, constant person greeted you each day for monitoring and later called you with instructions, it might feel a bit more personalizedTerrible billing system Very terrible billing system  They treat you like nameless, faceless cattle because that is what you are to them  They make an already very stressful process really more as stressful as possible and they just don't seem to care  So, it's pretty clear what they really care about I think it's hard to find someone in New York who doesn't just care about the money and know there will also be lots of patients in the pipeline, even if they get some bad reviewsI am writing this review 5 years after having my eggs frozen at NYU I just thawed and fertilized the eggs (at a different facility as I have moved) and had higher than average success rates The NYU clinic is associated with one of the best research universities in the world after all They do need improvement in some areas but are unlike commercial clinics that might look fancier but are exclusively for-profit My retrievals consistently went up under his careful monitoring and I didn't even do the acupuncture or yoga (Seriously, who has time for all these appointments, having a professional job to pay for this, plus time for yoga classes and acupuncture?)From a donor perspective: make sure to do your research! This was a great resource for me, straight from the New York Department of Health: healthOne of the nurses (there are three) was troubled by my questions related to potential medical risks for donors, and expressed this I'll update as those bills come in I found out I was pregnant a couple days before my appointment at NYU It was too late to cancel without financial penalty, so I went anyway They took blood for genetic carrier screening and many other things they didn't tell me about beforehand I wish they'd told me which tests they were running, since many were repeats of tests I'd had done recently and have records for The nurse called me same-day with my hCG level and said to come back in 2 days for a repeat to confirm my levels were doubling They told me to come back the following week for another blood draw I was confused because I'd initially been told I'd just need the first and 48-hour tests, but the nurse said it was necessary to confirm things were moving successfully 1/10 - Went back for another draw, got a call same-day from a nurse She said I had to return in a week for an ultrasound, although it would be too early to see a heartbeat, and I'd need another ultrasound the next week to look for a heartbeat) I said I'd prefer to wait until I was far enough to find a heartbeat, so I could just have one ultrasound instead of two)1/20 - Had a blood draw and transvaginal ultrasound The nurse didn't wash her hands or use gloves to prep the ultrasound probe (and she touched door knobs and a trash can) She said we still needed a repeat ultrasound in a week, but didn't clarify why The nurse said my blood from 1/20 wasn't run since the doctor saw what she needed on the ultrasound I wish they'd waited until after the ultrasound, so I could have avoided an unnecessary blood draw and bruised arm The nurse gave me the results from an earlier blood test that I hadn't received before My titers were checked a few years ago when I volunteered in a hospital and came back showing immunity) But anyway, the nurse said I needed to get the MMR and varicella vaccines ASAP and wait 30 days to get pregnant (Those are LIVE vaccines which are NOT given during pregnancy!)Nurse: "You need to go to a clinic to get the MMR and chickenpox vaccines Just wait 30 days to get pregnant"Me: "Ok well it's too late for that now, and I can't get the vaccines because I'm pregnant"Nurse: "If you're not going to follow our advice to get the vaccine, you'll need to sign a waiver saying you understand the risks There's also no online portal to check your own labs This place is a mill, they treat you like cattle But this is not even my main complaint The invoices are jibberish, but they keep sending them to us Every time we receive a bill it is like PTSD about our past failed cycles NYU Fertility Center is inhumane and really unpleasant to deal with I froze my eggs with NYU in 2012 and it was totally fine It was well organized and although there are a lot of people handling you and your visits, I felt they were competent and everything was done professionally The most difficult part of the process is the first time you come home with all the prescriptions and needles and you have to inject yourself for the first timeThe nurses are good at responding to voicemails, but their response is always to tell you to speak with billing  Their default start of conversation is always to ask "did you speak with billing?"  I've learned that if you press them, sometimes they will actually  look in your chart and see that there really is no need to speak with billingAnd I've found that billing only returns calls about 1 out of 4 times  I left message after message  When the woman from NYU returned from vacation and returned my call, she became upset with me because I had spoken to someone else in her department in billing!  It was really quite odd But, If I had waited, I would have missed that month's window  I've at various times waited two hours to be seen during morning monitoring - and double checked to see if my name had been called - have been told no, it hadn't, and then upon seeing the nurse, have been told that i was called earlier   It's very stressful  I was previously tested at another place and that should have been enough When i called Recombine, they told me they could reduce the payment, but refused to issue a new bill for me stating thisI agree with the others regarding doctors/nurses not giving much attention to you or your future Dr Berkeley will talk to you on the first day (and that's it), and after that, you will most likely only communicate with either nurses, coordinators, billing department, more nurses, and a 'day of' doctor payment plan, timing, your chart and what's missing, etc But, when I got the PGS result, I then was told (by a different nurse) that it was too late to take the pill now as I should have taken in on day 2 of the previous month But, they don't realize that the phone tag play is pretty awful I guarantee that they will not pick up your call (no matter which number you call), and you leave a vm, and if you ever miss their callback, good luck because when you call back, that will go to vm againBelow is the brief summary of our experience with NYU  * Terrible internal communication between the NYU staff (physicians and nurses) as I was repeatedly told erroneous or conflicting information/guidanceGreat Doctors, but HORRIBLE customer service  The Doctors are amazing, but the customer service and billing/administration is so bad I would just go someplace else if I had to do it all over again  When you call you NEVER get the actual folks at NYU Fertility, it just goes to an answering service over and over again  The service says someone will call you back within 3 hours and that never, ever happensWe've been around the block to different centers, and the people here are the absolute top Kind, helpful, compassionate, human Thank you, NYUI've recently did my first ever IVF cycle at NYU and my experience was really great! Nurses and staff were really efficient, straight to the point and nice I was dreading ER but my experience in OR was great! No pain after and nurses were very comforting when I woke up Overall the whole process was very smooth and much easier than I originally expected NYU has a great team of doctors, nurses, embryologists - I was really impressed)  Overall, I thought NYU was efficient and professional, and I'm very pleased with my experience  After that, you sign up for one of their egg freeze "orientations," which is a 2-3 hour presentation by a nurse about the details of the process (this was probably the weakest link in the experience, more on that below  (I ended up waiting a year, but didn't have to redo the consult)  You pick a pharmacy (I highly recommend Apthorp -- they deliver!), and NYU will call in your prescriptions  This was no issue as Apthorp will deliver same day, even when you call late afternoon  You go in for bloodwork on your day 2, and then that afternoon, if you're bloodwork is solid, you're cleared to start meds and they'll tell you exactly what to take and when, and when to come back into the office  (It's usually in 1-2 days, always in the mornings between 7-9 am)  Every morning you go in, they do bloodwork, and most often they will do an ultrasound also to check how you are responding to the stims  Then, that afternoon, a nurse will call you, give you your estrogen levels, and give you instructions on what to take for then next few days and when to come back  The nurse will call and tell you precisely when to take the trigger shot, as your procedure in the OR will be timed exactly to this time  The day of the retrieval, plan to spend 3 hours at the place -- an hour to change/talk to the anesthesiologist/wait around, 10-15 minutes for the procedure, and about 45 mins to an hour of recovery, where they give you water and crackers, and maybe pain meds if you need them for cramps  Overall, I was very pleased with the experience  It's true that you don't see the doctor much, if at all, after your initial consult, but I really did not mind as every doctor I saw (they rotate in the mornings to do the ultrasounds) was very competent and nice and I never felt that I was not in good hands  In the mornings when I went in, I would usually arrive around 8 am, and I rarely had to wait more than 5-10 minutes  And the whole thing would take no more than 20/25 mins if we did an ultrasound, and 5-10 if it was bloodwork only  There is definitely a "factory" feel to the process, and sometimes you feel guilty holding up the process by asking questions (they just move that fast), but I actually overall appreciated that quality, because it made the entire experience very efficient and not much of an intrusion into my daily routine  If you have questions in the process, you call the nurse's hotline and someone will call you back within 2-3 hours  In terms of areas for improvement, my only complaint would be the orientation process I thought it was long and drawn out and filled with a lot of useless info (e  Also, the nurse that did our orientation (both times -- I attended twice since I waited so long) was a bit strange and I thought somewhat inappropriate, but most importantly, long-winded and slow, making it an unhelpful 3 hours of my workday  I think the orientation should be shortened by half with the emphasis on 1) do's and don't's during the cycle; and 2) a quick demonstration of how to administer the shots (not an endless one, as I experienced, since there are videos online But, more so, their billing felt incredibly disorganized I was perplexed because days earlier I didn't have a balance at all and confirmed that my insurance still had not reached its cap for fertility treatments I have never experienced a more callous, money-hungry experience as a patient and would never return to this clinic againI am surprised to see so few reviews here of this clinic  You will be making regular visits, and it is the rest of the staff that you will be working with, and you will be super hormone'd up and extra sensitive, to boot  I had a few bad experiences with the staff, especially this super mean lady in the recovery room, OF ALL PLACES (when you are waking up from the anesthesia, from your procedure)  -- dang!  She was just super gruff and mean, and at one point just walked away while I was sitting alone and crying, during my intake for the procedure, when I was anxious and scared  Also, you feel a little bit like cattle, going through the processThe good stuff is: they know what they are doing, and I believe they are actually one of the clinics who helped make this whole field in the first place)Another "good" thing, if you can call it that, is that the injections that you give yourself - that you will dread - are really no bigs!  You can just watch the training videos a bunch of times til you feel comfortable doing it (that's what I did)  Needles have come a LONG way  It is all the stuff Michael Jackson was into :)  My recovery was also no bigs at all - can't say that I had any issues with thatI had the best experience here! I love the team and everything went so smoothly! I highly recommend you go to NYU you will not regret it I honestly cannot say enough about my experience here My doctor is amazing (Hodes-Wertz), the other docs I've interacted with are friendly and knowledgable,  and the nurses absolutely make the place Everyone here is efficient and kind Yes, you may not see your actual doc often - that's how it works at all fertility clinics They are very organized and know exactly where you are/what you need in every cycle Not only am I confident they are doing everything I need medically, but I feel genuinely cared for by nursing staff when I'm there  We didnt give up, but a few months later, our in-state fertility clinic dropped us after the 5th IVF because they couldn't figure out what was wrong   We decided to travel to New York and try NYU because they have one of the highest success rates in the worldTo anyone considering using NYU, keep in mind that the NYU team isn't there for emotional support  NYU is the best at what they dohelp give you the greatest gift of lifeThank you to the entire NYU team for not giving up on us when everyone else did!  We are very thankfulAll and all my experience at this facility was mediocre But the doctors don't really pay you much attention, literally running from room to room every morning My biggest issue with this place is billing, they can't get there act together Puts me on hold, she than comes back to say that I need to call the NYU fertility office and have them release the $950 to be paid to the anesthesiologist So I called the NYU fertility billing office, of course they leave a voicemail at 5pm when they close She states that the $950 is extra and told me to call another department He was inaccessible and his secretary at the time was new and not helpful Apparently he is only part time at NYU and also has another practice We would have an appointment with him regarding the IVF and it would get cancelled last minute and we had a first ultrasound appointment of fetus scheduled with him that also got cancelled The secretary did not inform us we should schedule the ultrasound appointment with any of the doctors so we waited and then found out we should do that and it was week 8 The nurses are helpful, especially Carol and Andrea and will answer your questions and call you back But they are busy and sometimes it takes a full day for them to get back to you which is nerve wracking when dealing with self administered scheduled shots  We had some miscommunication with billing and our insurance which also was frustrating leaving the patient in the middle to sort it out Billing does not call you back unless you hound them I've heard other places are similar- ie feels like a factory- so I'm not sure if this is standard for large hospitals that have good reputation for fertility treatmentSTAY AWAY FROM NYU! Horrible facility  The bigger problem was billing  My labs were sent to two different lab facilities on the same day and I was charged two co-pays, but nobody knew why they were sent to two facilities and why I was charged twice  I was not confident in my physician, I was not confident in her staff and I was not confident in the billing  I have been to many different places and I have never seen a more disorganized placeThis is an excellent fertility center We did 4 IVF cycles at Columbia, had consultations and Cornell and at New Hope, and then found NYU NYU was sooooo much better than any of the above The place is super-organized, morning monitoring is really efficient and quick (unlike, say, Columbia) Wouldn't send my friends/relatives any place else!  In the recovery room after the retrieval procedure, the nurses were making fun of on of the patient's who was experiencing hallucinations after the anesthesia  The weekend nurses had made multiple mistakes regarding when I come in and when I take my medication

This provided useful information on how everything would proceed Process begins! . I felt like the nurses were great, caring and competent . Later, the call comes with info about how much medication to take . For me, recovery wasn't bad I did not accept Tylenol and felt like I had very bad cramps for the rest of the day but they improved by day 2 . I've learned that if you press them, sometimes they will actually . When you call you NEVER get the actual folks at NYU Fertility, it just goes to an answering service over and over again . Overall, I thought NYU was efficient and professional, and I'm very pleased with my experience . I ended up waiting a year, but didn't have to redo the consult) . In the mornings when I went in, I would usually arrive around 8 am, and I rarely had to wait more than 5-10 minutes . There is definitely a factory feel to the process, and sometimes you feel guilty holding up the process by asking questions (they just move that fast), but I actually overall appreciated that quality, because it made the entire experience very efficient and not much of an intrusion into my daily routine . In terms of areas for improvement, my only complaint would be the orientation process I thought it was long and drawn out and filled with a lot of useless info (e . Reviews: I decided on NYU after doing a lot of research on egg freezing Egg quality is a mystery until you make embryos I'm going to do another cycle because more eggs = higher percentage of a positive outcome Other clinics often make you follow a generic protocol and shrug when you don't get results even though they should know that every body reacts differently to the medicine And they ask for $500 to give you your own eggs if you decide to transfer them elsewhere  We did two rounds of IVF and we able to get my daughter Did 3 letrozole cycles here, and had to ask after every failure to up my dosage (started at 2 When we decided to go somewhere else for IVF, it took over a MONTH to get the medical records  The surgical procedure itself was a breeze7) noting birth control pills sometimes affect them; AMH bumped to 188 after I stopped bc for 2 months  On my protocol I was on maximum Menopur (450 per day) I started taking ganirelix to prevent ovulation around day 6 Also, I strongly recommend icing to help make the shots more bearable  When they determine you are ready, they'll tell you a specific time to take your trigger shot; your procedure will be 35 hrs later Overall, I was lucky not to have significant side effects from any part of the process or procedure Before starting I wish I knew: (a) you can't exercise during the protocol OR for another 10-14 days afterwards! (b) The process is a big deal To be realistic about it: shooting yourself with hormones every day is grueling Results:  I ended up w/12 eggs; 11 fertilized, 7 became embryos & 3 were viable  Also - I was extremely disappointed that NYU did not recommend we provide multiple sperm samples, which led us to need ICSIThis place will force you basically to use donor eggs if you are above age 40[They also misrepresented the number of eggs they froze AND the number of embryos I produced (presumably so it my results would look/sound better) - luckily I switched facilities and my new Dr straightened this out 7 of the 9 eggs successfully thawed and 6 were successfully fertilizedI have undergone three egg retrieval cycles here One word of caution to people planning to freeze their eggs for future use:  it's fairly common to get between 5 and 10 eggs per retrieval, some percentage of which may not be mature enough to freeze (They do freeze the immature eggs, but at the moment, there is no way to get a human egg to mature outside of the ovary) The trouble with egg freezing is that people should probably have ~20 eggs banked if they donate at age 36-37 and want a 50% chance at a live birth He knows these processes so well that after a cycle or two, he masterfully tailors the drugs to what the individual patient can tolerate And if you have Dr Grifo, definitely let him do whatever he thinks best with your drug protocol He's got the art side of this process downgov/publicatio…I was on track to move forward with this procedure but ultimately decided not to do it at NYU There are medical risks associated with egg donation, and donors should go through the procedure fully informed of those risks She suggested because of irregular cycles I go straight to a fertility center for testing and potential medication 1/5 - Went back, had the blood draw, got a call same-day to say that my hCG had doubled and my pregnancy was progressing well She balked and said it was essential I do the early ultrasound because my blood test numbers had been low and there was concern about my pregnancy being viable She said my progesterone from the 1/3 and 1/5 tests was too low I asked her for my progesterone results from today's blood tests, and she said it wasn't taken (Ok, so why am I here going through all these blood tests if we're not going to actually do anything? Progesterone supplementation is controversial, but it would have been nice to at least have been given the chance to discuss with my doctor She said I was not immune to chicken pox, measles, or rubella"Me: "But I'm 6 weeks pregnant so what am I supposed to do?"Nurse: "It's up to you My egg freezing procedure was successful and was seamlessAlso - I would skip the Recombine Genetic testing that they recommend here 3) I was told that I could adjust the timing of my transfer with pills When I reached out to one of the coordinators to book the transfer date and/or to get the prescription for the pill, she said there is nothing she can do until we have the PGS resultI did one egg freeze cycle here and my review is based on that  I'll briefly describe the steps of their egg freezing cycle:  first, you go in for bloodwork on day 2/3)  I opted to order in small doses as needed since I didn't know what my protocol was going to be or how long I would be on stims  Once the doctor doing your ultrasound deems you "ready," they'll schedule your retrieval procedure, usually two days later, and instruct you to take a trigger shotI totally agree with the previous reviewer (G  Amen, sister!  You are so right on that  I would read up on IVF, the hormones, the injections you give yourself, the pain and discomfort that you will experience, and the procedure, before you proceed  After 4 unsuccessful IVFs with unexplained infertility, we were dropped by insurance who claimed our chances of having a baby were under 5%  After learning a lot through our 6th IVF, we did another  2 IVFs with successful resultsthey deal with facts and are there to help give you the highest probability of having a babyI had 3 unsuccessful IUIs and one successful IVF frozen with PGD testing Only one embryo came back for implantation- but we have a healthy beautiful baby girl - now three weeks old  She was pushing me to do a frozen embryo transfer, but I wanted a fresh cycle  I had 3 IVFs and 5 IUIs
summary: I decided on NYU after doing a lot of research on egg freezing Egg quality is a mystery until you make embryos I'm going to do another cycle because more eggs = higher percentage of a positive outcome Other clinics often make you follow a generic protocol and shrug when you don't get results even though they should know that every body reacts differently to the medicine And they ask for $500 to give you your own eggs if you decide to transfer them elsewhere . We did two rounds of IVF and we able to get my daughter Did 3 letrozole cycles here, and had to ask after every failure to up my dosage (started at 2 When we decided to go somewhere else for IVF, it took over a MONTH to get the medical records . The surgical procedure itself was a breeze7) noting birth control pills sometimes affect them; AMH bumped to 188 after I stopped bc for 2 months . On my protocol I was on maximum Menopur (450 per day) I started taking ganirelix to prevent ovulation around day 6 Also, I strongly recommend icing to help make the shots more bearable . When they determine you are ready, they'll tell you a specific time to take your trigger shot; your procedure will be 35 hrs later Overall, I was lucky not to have significant side effects from any part of the process or procedure Before starting I wish I knew: (a) you can't exercise during the protocol OR for another 10-14 days afterwards! ( b) The process is a big deal To be realistic about it: shooting yourself with hormones every day is grueling Results: . I ended up w/12 eggs; 11 fertilized, 7 became embryos & 3 were viable . I'll briefly describe the steps of their egg freezing cycle: . first, you go in for bloodwork on day 2/3) . I opted to order in small doses as needed since I didn't know what my protocol was going to be or how long I would be on stims . Once the doctor doing your ultrasound deems you ready, they'll schedule your retrieval procedure, usually two days later, and instruct you to take a trigger shotI totally agree with the previous reviewer (G . I would read up on IVF, the hormones, the injections you give yourself, the pain and discomfort that you will experience, and the procedure, before you proceed . After 4 unsuccessful IVFs with unexplained infertility, we were dropped by insurance who claimed our chances of having a baby were under 5% . After learning a lot through our 6th IVF, we did another . 2 IVFs with successful resultsthey deal with facts and are there to help give you the highest probability of having a babyI had 3 unsuccessful IUIs and one successful IVF frozen with PGD testing Only one embryo came back for implantation- but we have a healthy beautiful baby girl - now three weeks old . She was pushing me to do a frozen embryo transfer, but I wanted a fresh cycle .

Reviews: I was surprised when I learned he wasn't the one conducting my retrieval but he called me and put me at ease about who was doing the retrieval Fifth, it's expensive I slashed my living expenses where I could (ie, got a roommate)I had my first cycle out of the two covered by insurance done at another practice, which proved to be a waste of time and money The biggest issue with this facility is cost They seem to make up prices out of thin air For example, they charge $1,000/year for storage when many other places charge $350-600/year Most places charge $0-35 for this, which literally involves just pulling your vials from storage They require payment up front even when your services are fully covered by insurance In my case, they charged me their cash rate and it took me 4 months and hours of my time to get them to refund the overcharge (the difference between the cash rate and the insurance-negotiated rate that I should have paid)I chose NYU for my egg freezing because they are reputed to be the top facility for this procedure in the United States, if not the world  No reason to mess up your cycle because you forgot a vial or took the wrong meds I'm unlucky that my insurance won't cover providers outside of NYU Wrong bills to insurance and over charge many times on me All they do is to send you bills for services done a couple of years ago and supposed to be fully covered by insurance(My insurance was billed $10,453 for the consultation and first blood tests, of which I owe $3,138 I haven't yet received bills for the other three visits and sets of blood work Nearly TWO years after our last failed cycle, they STARTED sending us huge bills totalling many thousands of dollars These bills make NO sense, because NYU will not even give you treatment at the Fertility Center unless you pay EVERY CENT up front Avoid at all costs I now pay an annual $ 1000 fee to keep my eggs frozen, and I have been told by friends that can transfer them to other services at a cost of $ 1500 for 5 years  In the meantime, after speaking with someone below her at the office, I called insurance myself and relayed all the info - Insurance told me to go ahead with the procedure  I was told that Recombine would accept my insurance - and my insurance did pay them over $1500 for the carrier map testing, but yet I still received a bill from Recombine for over 4 hundreds dollars  (Even though they only charge people without insurance $345)  My husband and I got some tests done here and it was extremely expensive, even though the facility and lab were both in-network  We understand these things can be pricey but we didn't get a head's up or anything - just a massive bill I did 6 cycles there and each one was fine-tuned to my response with each cycle  (They also will check your insurance for you to see if any of the medications are covered I came in for my retrieval and they said they wouldn't do my retrieval unless I on-the-spot paid them $5k I'm 24 and have cancer, my oncologist referred me here because they give you a discounted rate to freeze your eggs ($6950 total) I was sent a bill of $6950, exactly the cost that was discussed prior to the egg freeze cycle I paid the full amount, than 2 months after the whole process is over they send me another bill for $950 for anesthesia Very frustrating when you think that bill is paid and they hit you with another one out of nowhere  I was charged a co-pay for my visit even though I have full infertility coverage  My insurance told me that they paid 100% of the claim and that I should not have been charged
summary: In the meantime, after speaking with someone below her at the office, I called insurance myself and relayed all the info - Insurance told me to go ahead with the procedure . I was told that Recombine would accept my insurance - and my insurance did pay them over $1500 for the carrier map testing, but yet I still received a bill from Recombine for over 4 hundreds dollars . ( Even though they only charge people without insurance $345) . My husband and I got some tests done here and it was extremely expensive, even though the facility and lab were both in-network . We understand these things can be pricey but we didn't get a head's up or anything - just a massive bill I did 6 cycles there and each one was fine-tuned to my response with each cycle . ( I was charged a co-pay for my visit even though I have full infertility coverage . My insurance told me that they paid 100% of the claim and that I should not have been charged
